b"-- In short, to support its current valuation, $APPF needs to continue to grow its profitability, but may struggle to do so given that spending remains high and competition is only getting more intense. \n\n-- It's unclear what moat protects $APPF market share and profitability."

b'-- International property markets are seen as a promising area of growth for $APPF, but that expansion comes with its own set of costs, including increased sales expenses, designing products for specific markets, and managing regulations and taxes, among other challenges.'

b"-- Not only is the larger market more competitive, but competitors have also increasingly entered the SMB market. The competition includes IBM, Accruent, Buildium, and Yardi.\n\n-- Yardi, for example, offers platforms that compete directly with $APPF's but at a lower price point."

b'-- As these opportunities started to dry up, $APPF began to target larger property managers - a more competitive market. \n\n-- To compete, it invested and continues to invest in more dynamic offerings, such as Property Manager Plus launched in 2018.'

b'-- One explanation for the decelerating revenue and increasing expenses may be that $APPF has picked all of the low hanging fruit.\n\n-- After gaining traction early on, $APPF\'s product likely "sold itself" to small and medium size property managers excited for ease and efficiency.'

b"-- $APPF's revenue growth has decreased the last four quarters from 33.75% YoY in Dec. 2019 to 23% YoY in Sept. 2020.\n\n-- $APPF's spending on sales and marketing and R&D has also increased and remained high over the past four quarters, eating into operating margins."

b'-- The ability to live up to its current valuation is the #1 concern for $APPF.

-- Based on current estimates, $APPF trades at 298x P/E ratio on 2020E earnings.

-- $APPF could struggle to support this lofty valuation due to slowing growth in an increasingly competitive market.'

b'-- Over the long run, it remains to been seen whether (1) competition increases and (2) $APPF has pricing power due to switching costs.\n\n-- For now, $APPF has proven itself to be a fast-growing and innovative company targeting a large and historically underserved market.'

b'-- Despite COVID-19 headwinds, $APPF is expected to continue to grow revenue at impressive rates. FY18 rev was $190M, FY19 was $256M, and FY20(E) is $311M.\n\n-- For the past three years, $APPF has maintained a strong gross margin of ~60%.'

b'-- Since releasing its core software platform in 2008, $APPF has continued to develop and offer additional services, including online marketing, electronic payment services, rental insurance offerings, and tenant screening.'

b'-- In addition to the core platforms, $APPF offers a range of fee-based Value+ services that it charges for on a per transaction basis, such as tenant screening.\n\n-- $APPF has turned a profit for the past 15 quarters (i.e. since 1Q17). The profitability fuels product innovation.'

b'-- $APPF offers affordable solutions for improving efficiency. Its core software platform costs $1.25 per unit with a minimum monthly spend of $250.\n\n-- Its advanced platform designed for property managers with 1,000+ units is $3 per month with a minimum spend of $1500.'

b"-- $APPF's core market of property managers is large and historically underserved.

-- Management estimates a $5B TAM for its property management software.

--  Many property managers have traditionally used manual processes (e.g. ledgers and paper checks)."

b'Spotlight: $APPF (YTD +67%)\n\n-- $APPF makes cloud-based software for rental property management companies. Its products simplify the process of managing a rental unit, including screening tenants, handling maintenance requests, collecting rent payments, and marketing properties.'
